posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This thread is for the spirited discussion of CRT displays - Televisions, monitors and projectors used for the playing of retro games!

>Try to keep things /vr/ related: Focus should be on 6th Gen Consoles and older. Slight off topic is fine so long as it's related to CRTs, such as later 16:9 models, HD models, etc. Systems with backwards compatibility are also safe territory, as are re-releases on newer hardware. PC CRTs are also welcome and appreciated.
>Produce OC! Bust out your camera and take photos of your CRTs displaying all sorts of games, featuring all sorts of tubes, using all sorts of signals. Getting good shots can be hard, but if you take enough, at least a few will turn out alright.
>Try and give as much information as possible when asking for info on a specific set, or troubleshooting an issue to expedite and help you may receive. As always, Google is your friend and we are your friends with benefits. Do people read this? Older archived threads aren't a bad place to look either; Seriously, there's literally 6 years of backlog at this point.
>Share appreciation for others choice of technology and personal philosophy of gaming. Always remember to show courtesy in your discussion and moderate yourselves first.

Limited discussion of video processing and scaling devices is alright, but remember to keep the focus on CRTs and CRT accessories.

CRT Pastebin (Never Ever) : http://pastebin.com/1Ri5TS3x
Guide to CRT Hunting : http://pastebin.com/H9H9L2LQ
Guide to Video Monitors : http://pastebin.com/pQX4N6gZ
General Purpose CRT Adjustment Guide : http://www.arcaderepairtips.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/guide_setup_adjust_arcade_monitors_v1.2.0.pdf
S-Video Pasta : http://pastebin.com/rH2h6C7W

I'm really torn about it. This new black Trinitron has much better geometry than my WEGA, probably by virtue of having a rounded screen instead of the WEGA's flat glass, BUT the convergence issue you mention is all too real. Subtitles in games like Shenmue (where subtitles are difference colors, not just white/black) look really awful, but otherwise this new Trinitron is absolute king for 8-bit and 16-bit games. I forget just how good Hard Corps looks on a big tube.
I read up about how to go about fixing convergence though and it looks like there's three ways to go about it, depending on the gravity of the issue.
>Move the Horizontal alignment physical thingy inside the chassis.
>Move the Vertical alignment rings around the yoke itself.
>Stick more convergence strips inside the yoke, maybe even move magnets around.
In my case, the convergence is only really off on the borders of the image, so I only really need to play around with the "convergence strips", whatever that is. Will look into some home-made strips though, since I really doubt I'll be able to find these things on sale at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9485672
>That's not how TVL works.
Stupid faggot, that's exactly how it works

TVL = Horizontal Resolution
SNES/Genesis after PAR adjustment = 292x224

Assuming no overscan you can display all detail with 292TVL and and anything more than that and it looks oversharpened.
But CRTs always have overscan so you can never get it perfect.

Example
Top
15 inch consumer CRT component

Bottom
500 line PVM 14 inch RGB

The lower TVL looks far far better
But even that isn't perfect since you have screen-door effect because of the dot pitch being bigger than the pixel pitch.
The only way to achieve perfection is near-neighbour scaling into 12000-20000 PPI displays which is still a long way off.

>>9488437
Oh hey good timing, you asked right as I was checking back on this thread
I had two wired Retrofighters Brawler64s that crapped out on me. Basically the analog stick started dropping inputs, so for example if you were running forward as Link in OoT he would stop and start - essentially unusable. Both had the exact same problem.
Unfortunately they both had fallen just outside the warranty window, and their support didn't even reply when I sent them like a "Hey, anything I can try to do to fix these?"
About a year later someone on twitter was asking about them, and I outlined that whole chain of events to them and said that I don't recommend them at all. From that tweet, their PR/customer support team reached out to me and ultimately actually shipped me two of the newer wireless versions by way of apology. And the wireless one has held up a lot better than the originals. At least, so far.
So maybe the takeaway is, they used to be utter crap, and now are (hopefully) a lot better. The analog stick on all of these these is just kind of weird though.

In the interim I used the wired Retro-Bit Tribute64 (which is modeled after the famous Hori N64 controller) and I actually liked this a lot better than any of the Brawler64s. The only problem with these is that the connector has an absolute death grip on the controller port, which is why I switched back to the wireless Brawler64 for right now - since I didn't want to be unplugging and replugging that controller all the time, and wireless controllers just keep things a bit more tidy. You know how it is.

There is an N64 controller purist on this board who will tell you that the analog stick sensitivity and deadzones of any of these 3rd party controllers is crap compared to the original - he's got charts and whatnot to back it up. He's probably right, but it's never really bothered me and or caused any real problems.

Of these I'd recommend the Tribute64 first.

I need some help /crt/.

My FW900 has just suddenly started refusing to turn on if it's cold. More specifically when I try to turn it on it'll make the initial degauss click, then a horrible loud fizzle noise and bright flashes will appear on the left and right parts of the screen. The protector mode will then be activated and the LED will flash amber. If I heat up the tube to a little above room temperature (it's fairly cold in the house) then it will turn on as usual, albeit it will sound a bit more crackly and staticky than usual. Once on it will stay on as long as I want even if the temperature drops back down. It was working perfectly then one day it started doing this without fail.

I've had my FW900 for many years with no issue, however I've just started using it daily. as winter has hit the temp has also dropped quite a bit but it never gets super cold in here. My best guesses are a bad solder joint or capacitor (it's always capacitors right?) but if someone has a more educated guess (which board/circuit) I'd super appreciate that.

>>9490051
>>9491313
Safest bet would be to open the thing and check all capacitors with an ESR calculator. Replace the bad ones with new capacitors of the same specifications and pray that it works.
When it comes to these old machines, capacitors are almost always the suspect number one because they tend to fail earlier and when they do fail (and they will), they bulge up and start leaking on the main board, so you want to take care of that as soon as humanly possible.
If you aren't one for soldering, you could ask someone to do it, but it's questionable whether professionals will work on CRTs nowadays. Definitely a good skill to have though or, in my case, know someone who does that kind of thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9492425
that's pretty tough to answer
generally with gen 7 imo you want to be on a modern TV because all of gen 7 supported 480p (and beyond), and your CRT will likely only support 480i
So while gen 7 consoles can output a 480i signal that works on consumer CRTs, the software was pretty much all designed for 480p (or 720p, in the case of most PS3 games afaik). So right out of the gate on a PS3, you're taking a huge quality loss when using a CRT just because of the signals it can handle.

Pretty much all of the "Wow, this looks way better than my old CRT!" talk comes from back in the day when people were viewing a 480i signal on their CRT and then switched to a 480p signal on their flatscreen during gen 7. And I don't really think there are any games where you'd be like, "Now THIS. THIS game was MADE for a CRT!!", that's all up to personal taste.

Anon, please don't do this. As other people have stated, you can find a great TV set for free or around 50 dollars or less price range, if you actually take the time to look. >Why the fuck does literally no one make a modern CRT?
It's because it's just too expensive. No one manufactures CRT TV anymore. The production cost was so low (insanely low) in the late 2000's for that reason alone. You could pick a mid to semi high grade CRT for 100 - 300 bucks brand new.
> I'm kind of treating these as a real TV purchase, not just for retro games like I said.
>I just want to also be able watch movies and TV shows on it in acceptable quality.
Be prepared to make some compromises you might not be thinking about. I have a Sylvania 6420FF (20 inches) I use for my bedroom TV and I don't think most modern consumers would care for that. If you want to use normal TV that way (over the air TV), you are going to need a converter box unless you have cable. I think CRT TV’s have their uses for sure (retro), but you need to use them in the best way possible. Think of it as a hobby TV, not your main one. They look great using old video game systems and DVD’s, but if you are approaching the HD stuff, it’s really not the best use for it. You'll be looking at 16:9 bars.

>>9496004
final fantasy 9 - timeless story and loveletter to classic final fantasy and looking back on it, the perfect sendoff to classic ff before it became the constipated dramatic shlock we have today. (despite that i enjoyed 10, 12, 14, and 15)

chrono cross - the music is great and the gameplay is from the phase squaresoft went through when they plopped out rpgs with weird/experimental combat systems. story is also good, i give it high marks since the original director consulted the localization dept so as to make sure nothing got lost in translation. i liked trigger but cross definitely hits the spot

mother 3 - i was a big fan of earthbound before it really caught on and became surface level popculture sludge. i spent quite a lot of my youth on the starmen forums and the mother 3 translation forums before the translation came out. the music is great and i love the combo system because it makes the gameplay a lot more engaging than earthbound which i found myself mashing A just to get through fights. still holding out that the mother 3 64 demo will get leaked one day

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Basically when games and technology started specifically aiming for a photorealistic picture, is when "retro" truly ended. To me what we call retro - both 2D and early 3D - is not about dates but rather about artistic merits of working around major technical limitations, which is what made those games so good. When every game looked absolutely different and unique because they were all hyper-stylized artistic depictions of reality seen through the prism of artistry of creative people. Not so much anymore when 90% of the entire development process goes towards making everything look how it does in real life - which is, you know, the same. When the 7th gen started we didn't just gain things like upgrades in storage space and resolution, for the first time in history we started progressively losing things, losing artistry, because there were no more major technical limitations to overcome. More and more elements started becoming token. So much so that we saw the rise of tertiary elements like online becoming more popular than the games themselves.

Nothing even remotely like that. They used digitized actors because it was easier compared to drawing sprites. The end result was just as cartoony tho, they never even attempted to deliberately strive for any sort of photorealism.
>the whole FMV fad
That was a completely separate convergent evolutionary dead-end. There were VHS-based games and so on. At that point you can say board games are photorealistic because you played them irl.

No, only in the 7th gen did games start deliberately and en-mass, which is key here, strive for photorealism in one way or another.

I wouldn't mind this definition but I also don't mind including GC/PS2/Faggotbox either. Looking back with the benefit of hindsight regarding what I hate the most about games & consoles today, I see that generation as being relatively pure. Experimental market-poking and prodding happened, but it wasn't the norm, and I fully expect to have to deal with these being called retro by my weaker brethren en masse someday.

With the Wii/PS3/Faggotbox360 they were becoming more committed to their modern, forwadd-looking hardware identity, but they were still only experimenting with the rot. It had evolved from a question of permissions to a question of facilitation. It was the Switch/PS4/FaggotboxOne generation where all three companies had fully committed to modern rot concepts. Their hardware angle was set and leaned into, their policy and strategy on the brave new werld of microtransactions, unfinished beta AAA releases, bloatgramming, and various other consumer abuses that old games lack were set and normalized.

Maybe retro can be defined by exactly in which ways companies abused consumers. Back in the day your lives were tied to a real life quarter that you popped into the machine, so the market wanted HARD games that you learned to play by dying repetitively. When the move to console came it wasn't long till this shifted. Instead of incessantly killing you (unpopular with millenials), the games were filled with meaningless content and time wasters. Companies believed that time spent playing on a home console was a sales leader driving new game purchases. Sounds right to me. Eventually it shifted again though, and everything reminds me of the itunes/googleplaystore now. I'm almost done typing. Microsoft is gay and if you pay them money you are also gay, good night /vr/

The actual retro is arcades and the age before the mass spread of personal computers and consoles. When games were programmed in universities by enthusiasts.

Afterwards it's much less distinct and there are several weirdly overlapping niches between actual consoles and various kinds of home computers. But the third large change, separating that zoo from what came next, is definitely 3D. This was the summit of ambition back then and in retrospect I don't understand how anyone who was alive and into video games back then didn't get sick of hearing "3D" all the time.

All this "six gen" and "seven gen" is completely alien even to that previous age because Mass Effect sure isn't retro in any way.
The "problem" lies with the board's name because if it actually was for retro games only it would've had activity comparable to /po/.

>Wrong. So backwards compatibility makes games not retro anymore? Ps3 plays ps1. I guess ps1 isn't retro now. Derp.
Let me rephrase it, for anons with poor reading comprehension.
Any consoles released after 1st January 2000 aren't retro. Games for these consoles released after this date would still be retro.
Final Fantasy 9 would still be a retro game since it was developed for and released for the PS1, a console that was first released in late 1994, despite the game itself being released in mid-2000.
So would Digimon World 3, despite being released in 2003.
For PC games the cut-off would be 31st December 2004, with some exceptions. Half-Life 2 can't really be considered retro, while Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines could, since it inherits so much from 2000's Deus Ex.

A new generations model, not based on years, but on hardware and gameplay:
1 - Pre-NES.
2 - NES-TG16-SMS.
3 - SNES-SMD-GB-PS1.
4 - PS1-N64-SAT.
5 - PS2-Wii era, incl. GBA and DS.
6 - PS3-360-WiiU era, incl. 3ds.
7 - Xbone-PS4 thru today.
Nintendo since Wii has dropped a generation behind the pack. I think the major problem with the previous model was basing it off of Nintendo's consoles as if they represented the pack, when really they are notable outliers. Look at them today especially, their main system is a handheld! To say the switch is the representative of modern gaming isn't entirely accurate, it more represents the previous generation's staying power.
Look at human beings. There are 4 or 5 generations living today. They are each different, but one's inception is not necessarily the other's demise. a generation lasts as long as it is able to compete for market space. 8bit did it for a whole decade on a puny B&W screen, but it stuck it out!

>Gen 7 (Early HD) - 360, PS3, Vita, Wii U, Switch

>Gen 7
Hell no. It's more of a Gen 6.5 console.
If you're saying that the Xbox could not handle the Vita's 960x544p resolution, then I beg to differ, as there are some 720p and even 1080i games on Xbox.
Also, the Switch is more of a Gen 7.5 console, as it's much more powerful than the Wii U, PS3 and Xbox 360, but not as powerful as the Gen 8 consoles.
For starters, the Crysis Trilogy looks and plays much better on Switch than on PS360.

I would also add the 3DO to Gen 4.5, the Philips CD-i is more Gen 4.
The Atari Jaguar is also part of Gen 4.5.
I don't know which generation the Virtual Boy would be but it would probably be Gen 3.5. The graphics are nearly as detailed as the SNES, but it's monochrome and the music is still clearly 8-Bit.

Atari 5200 and 7800 are also Gen 2. 7800 was outdated for its time and is part of why it failed, but not as much as the 5200.
The Lynx is Gen 3.
Commodore 64 is also Gen 3.

Calling the PS Vita a Gen 7 console is inaccurate.
The Vita is nowhere near as powerful as a PS3.
For starters, the PS3 can run MGS3 in 1280x720p at 60fps, while the PS Vita runs it at 720x448 at 30fps, literally OG Xbox-tier.

>>9490685
That said, it still ran most games at 480i or 480p.
720p and 1080i were only on a handful of games, and some were probably not even native 720p or 1080i.
And even the PS2 had 1080i in some games like Gran Turismo 4. And that game was not native 1080i.
Lastly, the PS Vita had a 960x544 screen and most games were in that resolution, which is in this limbo of being too high to be SD but too low to be HD.
There are games with lower resolutions, though, and the Vita TV can be hacked to render select games like Persona 4 Golden and Catherine: Full Body in 1280x720p or 1920x1080i.

>>9483981
You just let the OPL desktop software a folder on your computer (mine's on a laptop) and set it up to be sharable. Pic related, there's only three folders you care about and the full art asset set can be downloaded pre-formatted at under 200mb

From my cheat sheet:

>04/26/2021

>This is a SHARED FOLDER FOR OPEN PS2 LOADER, CONNECTED VIA ETHERNET CABLE
>-I configured a static IP address on my network adapter for this; you'll have
>to go to network and sharing > change adapter settings > ethernet > IPV4
>to convert it back to dynamic IP from current static

>I changed share settings for home and public; might want to lock those back down.

>If you want to remove the shared file path (C:\***\PS2SMB), go to properties/sharing/advanced sharing/uncheck 'share this folder'

>>9484171
OPL is short for Open PS2 Loader. It's software you run on your PS2 that lets you boot games from an internal hard drive, a USB drive or via your network using SMB.
It's pretty sweet, honestly. You can buy a memory card online for maybe $15 tops that's preloaded everything you need to run it on your PS2. You just plug the memory card into either slot before the console boots and you're good to go.
Setting up OPL itself is another matter entirely, but it's really well documented.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9484165
>>9484417
It's also an accompanying managerial application what you use to properly format ISOs (IE, make sure they're named with the proper formatting), manage art assets, and convert CD-format PS2 games (Bin+cue) to ghetto ISOs you can play through the utility

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9484643
>Is there any difference between the IDE to SATA converters? Obviously it's all chinkshit, but is it all pretty much the same?
I noticed there's some that don't have the master/slave switch. This is a thing I became aware while homebrewing my Xbox. I don't know if that would cause any problems. Due to the low price the only option is just to try them out.

>I think I saw that you could use a 3.5 or a 2.5 drive, but I assume a 2.5 would be better for the space. I just don't know what all of this looks like once its in the guts of the machine.
I use SATA drives (2.5 ones). This is how it looks. It kind of dangles from the network adapter. As long as you're not moving the PS2 around there is no danger of it falling off. Somebody sold 3D printer "holders" to make it more sturdy, but I haven't had any problems in a year of using this setup.

>And for HDDs, is there an upper limit on specs that the PS2 even benefits from?
I think the limit is 2 TB but that's really overkill. The main issue is that any HDD you obtain has to be detectable by the PS2 for formatting. It may well be that the expensive HDD you buy simply won't be detected and there is nothing you can do. My suggestion is to salvage some SATA HDDs from old laptops or second-hand stores. I got two 500 GB and one 320 GB drives this way and only cost me $30 from a guy on facebook marketplace. All of them worked, luckily.

The PS2 won't benefit from higher speeds since most games have tied logic to the PS2 reading speed, so its capped.

The current program used for feeding games to the drive is called HDL-Batch. It has been updated this year and I literally used it yesterday. Now it has an user interface and can tell you if the ISO is corrupt or if its already in the drive etc. You format the drive in the PS2, get it out and connect it to the PC with an USB to SATA cable (very cheap), the program dectects the drive and you just select the games you want to install.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9484864
>Would a 3.5" drive still dangle, or sit more flush?
The 3.5 IDE drive will just fill the space so there would be no dangling. The space was made for those in mind.
I opted for the 2.5 SATA drives due to the issues of:
- needing the SATA to IDE adapter OR the original PS2 network adapter.
- needing to get an IDE to USB for the PC (the IDE needs it's own power so it will turn on in the Xbox/PS2 but not when you connect it to the PC with the SATA to IDE adapter).
- the internet scared me with stories of IDE drives dying out of the blue.
- the current abundance of SATA drives being thrown for pennies by people who don't know better and me being unable to find an IDE drive that wasn't being sold full-price/new.

>Oh, you don't just do all that through Explorer file management? I guess I didn't notice that when reading this stuff.
Windows will just not even acknowledge you added connected a drive if it's formatted for PS2. Yes. It's confusing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9485430
Obviously the hard drive goes in the PS2.
OPL has an option to format it for PS2 use, regardless what was in it before.
It just needs to recognize it (there's a website for compatibilities but its incomplete and given the unlikeness of finding the exact drive it's better to get it for cheap).

Once formatted you can add games to it. The fastest is to take the drive out and connect via USB to the PC.
Windows won't recognize the drive, but if you use HDL batch it will appear there. There you just select the ISOs and BIN/CUEs you want to add and it loads them up.
There are other ways to add stuff like network or USB but that's slow as fuck.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9485789
It couldn't hurt to grab a game or two that you're interested in since there's still some good stuff that can be had for cheap out there, but if I were you I would throw CFW on your new PS2 and get some way to play ISOs going. You'd definitely get the most games for your money that way, and 99% of stuff works exactly the same as it would from a real CD or DVD with a little bit of setup.
If you read this thread there have been several posts with good resources about where to get started. Basically, you'll need a memory card with Free MCBoot preinstalled (you can get these on eBay or Amazon) and you'll need to install OPL Manager on your PC to manage your games. If you have a fat PS2, you should spend a little more money and get a hard drive set up for it. If you have a slim you should stick to playing games over ethernet. You can play games over USB on ether model, but it's not as good as the other methods.

posts.com:
>>9493123
I think it's a matter of people wanting a hassle free solution, like the original xbox or wii. I have around 950 PS2 games on my 2TB HDD and just a couple of games didn't work, which was solved by using an older version of OPL.

OPL has some plugins enabled by default and even though they can be useful, it breaks a good % of games. One unlocks the read speed of the HDD so games load as fast as possible and the other is called IGR (In-Game Reset), which enables you to reset the console with a combination of buttons. For games that don't boot, you have to turn off one of these plugins. Problem is, many people don't know you can have game-specific configs, so they see a game that doesn't work and call it quits.

When you launch an online game for the first time, many of them have a network setup software. In here, you can setup up your DNS. The good thing is that you can create multiple profiles, so you can have 3 or 4 network profiles with different DNS. These profiles are saved to the memory card and are compatible between games, so you don't have to setup a new network profile for each game.

>>9498082
PS2 games (or anything SD for that matter) really doesn't look that great on modern HD / 4K TV's. It can really be a night and day difference when displayed on a CRT, compared to a modern TV setup. I think emulation on a PC might help, since it can upscale everything. It also really matters what cables you are using on a modern display. I tried playing my GameCube (Resident Evil remake) on a HDTV with S-Video output and it was almost unplayable. I would suggest using a CRT but I also understand a lot of people don't have the time or room for a setup like that.

>>9491679
The original is a pretty good game in its own right.
Something to note is that the UE1 engine games (Unreal, Unreal Tournament (sequel) have some compatibility problems on modern systems. Patch both with their latest Old Unreal patches and this is my subjective opinion, but stick with the legacy Galaxy audio system for sound. The other audio systems have different quirks that affect how effects and music are mixed and propagated in the games and they don't feel quite right to people that have played them before, someone new might not care but still the right choice imo.

Also the games are supposed to have some neat looking volumetric fogsl effects, but sometimes the games automatically disable it because of outdated hardware checks. You'll have to read about how to force them back on in the advanced preferences menu of the engine if they get disabled.

Unreal Tournament has a full campaign ladder mode for solo play that takes you through pretty much all the game's content. UT:GOTY features a new Skaarj hybrid team and a revised campaign ladder with different maps, omitting an iconic map 'Barricade' that I actually kind of liked. There's a one line setting in an .ini file for switching the game back into its original 1999 state if you want. All maps can be found in the practice menu for custom matches.

UT2k4 has a slightly less developed campaign mode that only gives you a fraction of the total content. Use Instant Action to explore the full game.

Unreal 2 is mediocre, but it doesn't suck, imo.

What does it come with?

I think the best Unreal game is UT 99 by a hair. 2004 is also exceptional, and I could understand preferences either way. So on that alone I'd probably play 99 for 2k4 first depending on what looks better to you and then if you like one try the other one. Both have surprisingly competent singleplayer campaigns. UT99 still has a multiplayer scene but unless you are experienced in this type of game you'll probably spend most of your time eating shit.

Unreal and Unreal 2 are also very good games in their own right. The original Unreal is a bit of an odd FPS in that the pacing is really slow, but it's also absolutely brilliant visually and if you get into it the atmosphere is fantastic. It's fairly long, though, and if you don't like it in the first five hours you can safely drop it. It's definitely not for everyone.

I haven't played Unreal 2 since it launched, but I liked it quite a bit at that time. Come to think of it, that's basically the only thing I remember about it.


(So the racist Quake guy doesn't waste his time responding to my posts: Yes, Q3A is a better game than any of the Unreal Tournament games. I'd also say the original Quake is better than any UT. That doesn't change the fact that it's still a very strong series with multiple exceptional games.)

I just feel like the actual core gameplay in 2k4 is meh, meaning the deathmatching. The actual team-based modes are actually really fun, and great! ...but they don't feel like Unreal. UT2003 also doesn't feel like Unreal that much, but even worse about it because that game was really pushing the whole objective-based gameplay and had severe balancing issues.

>>9498154
Castlevania 1's a much tighter game with a better hard mode (not being able to start a run on it sucks, though), 3's got shitloads more replay value even discounting how the JP version is fairly different, Bloodlines is a much more engaging and fast paced game and Rondo has better presentation and boss fights. 4 isn't bad, it's just the least impressive of its contemporaries. It often gets held up on a pedestal for the same reason Mega Man X4 does: it was the easiest entry, had strong presentation, was on a popular system and was many people's first taste of the franchise after the initial interest boom on a prior system. It's why fans who overzealously elevate both games tend to resort to "YOU STOOPID" as a comeback to dissenting opinions: the attachment is mostly rooted in gut feeling and circumstance.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9498157
Konami had a policy of

A. Making games with the same name for brand confusion purchases.
B. Making alternate games for different consoles to build their fan base through product variety (if one isn't popular, the other likely will be).
C. Flooding the market with cheap games to crowd out competition.
D. Making what were essentially altered remakes to keep dev costs down.

They were fucking cut-throat. Nintendo had to enforce a game-per-publisher limit on Famicom to stop companies like Konami from hurting both the Nintendo brand and hurting partner sales, and Konami just made a shell company to get around it.

This is why you have Akumajou Dracula (FC, MSX, Arcade, SFC).

>>9498054
Two problems with the control specifically.
1. The ability to flail your whip is completely superfluous outside of the Dracula fight and the fact that it activates whenever you hit a directional button while attacking means that buffering movement while trying to attack will randomly make your whip go flaccid when you're trying to get a crucial second hit on something. This is also a problem when you're jumping and trying to attack and air-control at the same time, your attack will cancel mid-windup because the game thinks you're trying to flail in mid-air for some reason.
2. Eight-directional whipping renders several combat sections completely trivial to the point that it seems as if it was designed without it in mind.

Other problems:
>Swinging from grapple points is a dumb, irritating movement gimmick that always feels dangerous and slippery
>The 8-2 platforms can give you unwinnable patterns and the B-2 stairs are too punishing
>Because the combat is so trivial, frustrating platforming becomes the only legitimate challenge and is not fun
>Most boss fights are brute-force slugfests
>A few of the music tracks are completely absurd (3-3)
>Hard mode is nothing but more ambush bats

All that being said, it's still a really good, really fun game. It just has problems that people notice when they play it.

People were burning their copies of SMB2 on the streets. The police was everywhere. It was on TV 24 hours a day. Yamauchi was forced to testify before congress. He said he knew everything and still let the game be released. People were throwing turnips at him when he left the court. He resigned from Nintendo that very day. The next day yen collapsed.
Anyway, yes, I did know from the mags about it.

It’s just a good party game, it’s not a masterpiece and it’s not shit, it’s just good.

posts.com:
The Doomslayer in GMOTA is interesting because it's probably the first time a mod adresses the Sentinel from nuDoom and "expands" on them (because they barely had material at the time before Eternal)
Mostly because a lot of 2016 inspired mods are essentially "backporting" things that exist (even if not 100% faithfully) and GMOTA as a mod has a specific concept in mind, so the nuDoom/Slayer stuff (and the made up stuff for it) is a minor part
But between how limited Doom Eternal's modding is and some drawings people made of "original demon designs inspired by DE", i wonder if it'd take some "new Doom in old Doom" mod or Slayer's Testaments to "expand" the aesthetic/mechanisms of the new games
Like, imagine if someone did a small wad inspired by Urdak and made up a bunch of enemies based off the Maykrs, with a few based off actual concept art
And this is if a "classic take" on Urdak and Sentinel doesn't get creative, since the UAC/Hell are also portrayed differently in these new games
I remember Wad overdose on Doomworld doing "sprite" versions of someone's made up Eternal designs
I actually wonder about D3 having "original demons" too because stuff like the Arachnotron is based off official concept art and you had a PE and Baron that looked like modified Caco's and Barons
Pic related aged thanks to TAG2 but i also think the purple goo attack could suit a different demon design

Yeah especially with that purple sky. It can also help make some others realize how decently contrasted the game is, not just with lighting but hues as well.
Going from what >>9493248 mentioned regarding the palette, that’s something a lot of these devs were steering towards: Slightly to severely less saturated color palettes. You’re not likely to find a “blue” in the build trio that’s as vibrant as what you can find in Doom, Heretic, and Hexen.
>A bizarre yet beautiful stepping stone to full 3D.
Not really related to much, but I find the transition of Blood to Blood II morbidly fascinating: They went from having some of my favorite sprites out of any 90s shooter to one of the most unpleasant looking early 3D shooters I’ve seen.

I've changed up Doomslayer's pistol a little more to be a shotgun blast of the stun pellets instead of just one, it also now passively recharges instead of needing to be charged by attacking. This was done cus it was WAY too easy to combo back and forth between the Thunderbuss and the stun pistol and just lock anything down forever.

I also changed up the True Flight dagger a little, originally it just flew forward forever with no drop off, now it does that and it's capable of redirecting itself when it bounces off walls, it's really goddamn funny throwing this thing down a hallway and hearing something get hit a few moments later. The Greed knife no longer spawns ammo on hit, instead you now just throw three at once for big health regen.
Finally you can't really see it here but the Thunderbuss doesn't respond to reload or zoom inputs if you can't use those tools. No more holding the button and just cancelling out for free. Blaz is pretty much good to go at this point, so it's Doomslayer needing those last few tweaks to make him feel good to use and still be reasonably balance.

Fuck the filesize limit again. The first webm I made was too big so I had to re-re-record and process another one. Christ.

That was a bullshit excuse. "Westerners" back then were better at video games than easterners, the audiance actually seeked a challenge. In the west, most magazines had a challenge rating, for instance Nintendo Power had "lasting challenge", that or the "lastability" grade was heavily based on the game's difficulty and not just how many levels there were, in other words the harder the game was, the better the grade. Tons of action games were made harder for the west and it wasn't just because of "rentals", and the inverse is also true, western action games like Battletoads were made easier for the Japanese market.

Meanwhile in Japan, no such "challenge" rating in magazines and the audiance complained that even mainstream jRPGs were too hard (Final Fantasy 2, 3, Mother, Dragon Quest 2, etc).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9498940
There are a number of sources that mention the coin shortage in Japan that was caused by the popularity of Space Invaders and other arcade games. Here are a few examples:

In a 1980 article in The New York Times, it is mentioned that "the success of Space Invaders and other electronic games has contributed to a coin shortage in Japan that has prompted the Government to import coins from abroad and to encourage people to use paper money for small transactions."

A 1981 article in The Guardian also mentions the coin shortage in Japan and attributes it to the popularity of arcade games, stating that "the games craze, which began with Space Invaders, has contributed to a severe coin shortage in Japan."

A 1982 article in The Seattle Times mentions that "the coin shortage in Japan, caused by the popularity of Space Invaders and other video games, has prompted the government to ask people to use paper money for small transactions."

These articles provide evidence that the popularity of Space Invaders and other arcade games contributed to a coin shortage in Japan in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9498978
Arcade owners typically collect the coins that are inserted into arcade machines and then deposit them at a bank or other financial institution to be exchanged for paper money. In this sense, cashing in the coins at the bank would remove them from circulation and help to alleviate a coin shortage.

However, it's important to note that the coin shortage in Japan in the late 1970s and early 1980s was not caused solely by the arcade industry. The popularity of Space Invaders and other arcade games contributed to the coin shortage, but it was not the only factor. Other factors included a general increase in the use of coins for small transactions and a decrease in the production of coins due to a shortage of raw materials.

In any case, cashing in the coins at the bank would likely have helped to alleviate the coin shortage to some extent, but it may not have been sufficient to completely solve the problem on its own.

Just the country games are good? Any other Rare games that are worth checking out?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9498973
Assuming this isn't a joke, basically play everything.
>Donkey Kong
>Donkey Kong Jr
>Donkey Kong 3
These are all solid arcade games. Personally I love 3 because it's a very interesting take in the shooter games which were popular at the time.
>Donkey Kong (Game Boy, 1994)
At first it seems like it's just a Game Boy port of the arcade game but it's actually an entirely new game and is one of the best games on the Game Boy. This is also where a lot of Mario's modern moveset was introduced and some of those moves appeared again later on Mario 64
>Donkey Kong Country
>Donkey Kong Country 2
>Donkey Kong Country 3
Great games, among the best on the SNES. Don't let these go unplayed. At least play the first one.
>Donkey Kong 64
If you liked 90s 3d collectathons then this is your game.
>Donkey Kong Country Returns
>Donkey Kong Country Tropical Freeze
These last two aren't retro, but they are really good games and Tropical Freeze in particular is amazing. Especially the music.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9490142
anon, even the best-optimized 3D games on it had low framerates and low res. and most of them were crappy racers with tiny drawing distance.
i think there's a whole breed of retards who think GBA being 32 bit meant it had same specs as PSX, and that Nintendo just "didn't work hard enough on 3d". except unlike PSX, GBA had no real GPU or 3D hardware. if you understand what this means, you know you will need the CPU to render everything, and it will be done at a very slow speed.
pair this with the need for batteries, tiny res, lack of analog, etc., and you will understand why it didn't have much 3D.
and yes, surely, 20 years later some dedicated autists managed to put Tomb Raider on GBA, but no one would have time and money to bother with this back in the day when the system's life cycle was only 3 years.
instead, you got smooth good 2D and actually good 2D games. virtually of the 3D GBA titles I've played were shovelware racers, gimmicky trash and yuroshit. so I'm glad that GBA devs went with 2D instead of chasing 3D.

>>9496372
>Why do people call it a "life cycle"? Shelf life perhaps, but the GBA doesn't cycle by any stretch of the imagination.

There were games being released for the GBA up to 2008. I would say Nintendo supported it well enough. The GBA was doing great sales wise, but Sony decided to enter into the hand held market with their PSP, that supported sub level PS2 style graphics and has a disc drive. The PSP looked futuristic compared to the GBA. Which caused Nintendo to literally throw the DS into development, because they were scared of losing the handheld market, like they were the home console market. Nintendo smartly put more focus on the DS as a 3D machine, as it is better specced than the GBA. The DS has the GBA hardware in it, and it is used to control the second screen. Nintendo was able to get away with selling the GBA alongside the DS, through backwards compatibility.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9499186
As zoomies say, sounds like a skill issue.
But really, yes it sucks if you die on MB and have to restock. But it makes the first attempt that much more toe-curling and intense. The first time I fought MB was exciting, and so was the tenth, because of that decision alone. It punishes failure heavily, but it never ends the game for you. A determined player can easily kill MB without taking a hit, if they choose to keep trying the fight rather than stock up on health. It's really a big defenseless creature, once you figure out how to freeze the spaghetti-o beams. And there are good spots to replenish your supplies nearby, as well as an E-tank very conspicuously placed near the entrance to the fight. I think that particular detail alone proves it was a conscious, deliberate decision, and I consider it to be effective and fun.
Of course, I first bought the game when I was like fifteen, and I've always enjoyed a stiff but fair challenge in my games, so I can understand a 7 year old being really, really frustrated with it if they're used to more beginner-friendly fare. But a plunge into the depths of a hellish, alien environment where every living thing is hostile and a biomechanical supercomputer is observing your every move should absolutely not be beginner friendly, no matter what modern games would have you believe with their onscreen tutorials that stay there until the credits roll. It's beyond a cliché at this point, but they do not makes games like this one anymore. Some will be pleased about that fact. I am not. But I'm happy I still get to play this game.

Make one mistake, have to fight a guard, you're in a life and death duel, which the melee combat is actually pretty tense and fun, except there's 20 guards in the level. Meanwhile if you sneak up on them and hit them in an extremely specific area in the small of their back, it knocks them out instantly. Makes no sense.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9495706
Adding more objectives on higher difficulties is the only good option the designers had. It's boring to just add more guards on a higher difficulty (which it does, but it's secondary to the new objectives) or the even worse option of changing their behavior. You're playing a stealth game, so the inability to kill guards is important to make sure you stay undetected and be more careful instead of: "Oh well, I was careless and got caught, time for a sword fight!" Having to get in a sword fight (or run away on difficulties that prevent killing) works, because Thief (or more accurately Thief 1) is meant to evoke tension and fear of getting caught and to stray you away from confrontation. The blackjack (note: there is no specific spot you have to hit guards with it, you can do it from any direction, even the front, provided they aren't in combat) works as a mechanic, because the choice to use it or not use it changes the way the game it played, if you knock guards out you get the burden of hiding their bodies, so other AI don't see them. And if you choose to not use the blackjack, then the only suitable playstyle is ghosting (not alerting anyone to the point where they start to search for you) which makes the game even more difficult to those who desire while also changing the way you play.
The beauty of Thief comes down to letting the player form a playstyle without having them pick a class or such, but from the game's mechanics, Thief gives you so much freedom of approach while only making restrictions when necessary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Nintendo 64 games run at high resolution
Majority of N64 games run at standard 320x240 resolution. Some games support higher resolution with the expansion pack but less than a dozen reach 640x480. For the rest it's some weird resolution like 400×440 or 480x360.
https://nintendo.fandom.com/wiki/Nintendo_64_Expansion_Pak
>Nintendo 64 games have higher polygon count than PS1 games
N64 supports 160000 polygons per second with standard microcode. If you switch off some hardware features like Z-buffering, N64 theoretically can reach 500000-600000 polygons per second but these would be very basic unfiltered and untextured polygons.
PS1 has 180000 for textured polygons and 360000 polygons per second for untextured polygons. Most games use a combination of two.
In practice, no N64 game has a polycount outside of PS1 capabilities.
>Nintendo 64 games have bad textures because of cart size limitations
Only partially true. The most significant bottleneck is 4kb texture cache which takes CPU cycles to be updated. In short, the bigger textures you use, the worse framerate you have.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9493759
Lots of reasons. It's been known since forever ago that Woolsey didn't deliver the most faithful translation, not to mention all the censorship, which is why we got that old Sky Render fan translation over twenty years ago (that we now know to be amateurish as fuck). Then the GBA game came out, and its translation was recognized to be much more accurate, but it had two problems: first, by that point, Woolsey's script had obtained meme status, and while the GBA script kept some of his lines, it changed or tossed enough of them out to piss a vocal part of the fanbase off. Second, the GBA version had problems of its own, namely shit music, slowdown and lower resolution, among others. So now you have a bunch of Woolsey fanboys who like the idea of a more accurate script while still staying true to the Woolsey "flavor", all on the mostly superior SNES version, and before long, we got the Ted Woolsey Uncensored hack. Problem is, its creator didn't know a lick of moon, so all he did was mix and match bits and pieces of the Woolsey, GBA and Sky Render scripts as he pleased, and to top it off, he decided to also make it an overarching "game improvement" hack that fixed a gorillion longstanding bugs and added QoL changes. This effectively set the mold for all like-minded hacks that followed, all of which were made by people with no nip-speaking credentials, and all of which were convinced they could do it better than the last, especially given they're not constrained to just script changes, but outright game changes as well, so every new release is just feature creep. It's telling that it wasn't until like last year that we got a simple, no frills port of the GBA script to the SNES version.

tl;dr autism and one-upmanship

Is Legacy of Darkness an enhanced version or a sequel?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9499029
The former, but also a prequel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9499029
The N64 game was supposed to be 4 mostly unique campaigns. They ran into trouble during development and cut it down to two campaigns where 3/4 of the content is shared.

Legacy of Darkness is an attempt to deliver the other half. You play as one of the two cut characters in a prequel story with remixed versions of the levels and better controls/camera. Then you play a very short sequel story with a character who's based on the gameplay style of the other cut character. Then you unlock the two characters from 64, but their campaigns use the remixed levels from LoD and are consequently missing content.

So it's the second half of the game with a funny remix option for the first half as an apology.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9499201
It's like this:

The original game is Levels 1-4, Level 5A (Reinhardt)/5B (Carrie), Level 6, Level 7A/7B - 8A/8B, Levels 9-11. Carrie and Reinhardt share most of their campaign, and most of their exclusive levels are in the back half of the game.

In Legacy of Darkness, you have Level 0 (new intro level for everyone), Level 1Remix (Old first level is now second level and redesigned a bit for everyone), Levels 2-4 (virtually unchanged for Reinhardt and Carrie), Level C-1 (New level for Cornell, not encountered by Reinhardt or Carrie), Level 5A/5B (only meaningful change is adding the bosses for these levels that were cut late in dev for 64), Level 6 (only Reinhardt and Carrie even encounter this, ripped straight from 64), Levels C-2 and C-3, Levels 7A/7BRemix and 8A/8BRemix (the two character dependent levels are reworked lightly, almost unquestionably for the better), and Levels 9-11.

Which is all to say that Reinhardt and Carrie's campaigns are identical to C64 except
>New intro cutscene and level
>Original intro level has been redesigned.
>New boss fight.
>Four levels (two per character) were redesigned.
They still have all the same cutscenes from the original. There's some aesthetic changes (lighting, camera angles in gameplay, textures, color grading, Reinhardt's default design, both characters' secret outfits), but it's the same campaign.

If you're not the kind of person who needs to see Vanilla Dark Souls 2 and Scholar of the First Sin to compare them, there's no point in playing 64.

>>9498435
If you play against Stockfish on chess.com, you can check a box to enable showing what the computer is thinking.
It evaluates moves by looking at each move for each piece it can move on the board. The computer then plays ahead a few turns for each of these moves, assuming you'll play perfect counters to each of it's moves.
After doing all that, it ranks the moves base on how strong it's position was after those simulated turns.
For Stockfish on chess.com, it'll usually show you it's top 3 moves, and it's predictions for the next 10 turns based on those moves.

Setting the difficulty level basically adjusts a probabilistic model of which of those top 3 moves the computer will choose.
If you set it on easy, the computer will mostly choose the worst of the top 3 moves, and if you set it on hard, it will mostly choose the best possible move.

Stockfish also scores how aggressive or defensive moves are, and you can also tweak that so that it will give preference to one or the other.
It can also do fun things like analyze your moves to tell if you've mostly been playing defensively or offensively and adjust it's move preferences to better counter you.

Thread for introducing anon's to classic point & click adventure games.

>What qualifies as a classic point & click adventure game?
Games which are first person or isometric, which require movement or progression from using a pointer to advance, pick up objects, and/or solve puzzles. They can be 2D sprites, FMV, or 3D.

>POINT OF THIS THREAD
If you are a P&C virgin, or are somewhat new to P&C games, or simply don't care but would be interested in exploring more of them, this thread is for you. Just ask for recc's for anything in particular.

>RESOURCES
UNIVERSAL HINT SYSTEM - If you are forced cheat and look up the solutions to puzzles, do it through this website. It does not give you the answer to puzzles outright, instead opting to give you more and more detailed hints, and has virtually every single classic, as well as many new, P&C games.
https://www.uhs-hints.com/

ADVENTURE GAME DATABASE - Has nearly every single adventure game you could possibly think of, with the genre's they belong to, screenshots, availability, platforms, development info, and a summary of the game.
https://www.adventuregamedb.com

DEAD END GUIDES - Websites which blatantly state all the known dead-end states in the most well-known Sierra franchises.
https://kingsquest.fandom.com/wiki/Dead_end
https://policequest.fandom.com/wiki/Dead_End
https://spacequest.fandom.com/wiki/Dead_End

Roberta Williams
Tim Schafer
Al Lowe
Ron Gilbert
The Coles (Corey Cole, Lori Ann Cole)
Steve Meretzky

Even if you don't include puzzle solving, for some bizarre reason, there's still plentiful examples, such as the Quest for Glory games, the Conquests games, the Indiana Jones games, Even in games with no combat mechanics, you still directly and indirectly "fight" various enemies, such as in King's Quest 1 where you fight/defeat a Giant (which you defeat with a slingshot), a Dragon (which you defeat with a bucket of water), a Troll (which you defeat with a goat), and a Witch (which you push into a boiling cauldron), and there's examples like this in most point and click games.

But even still, going back to your original point, Quest For Glory 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 all have a consistent time-based events system. The Colonel's Bequest is another one, along with Conquests of the Longbow. Even Secret of Monkey Island has combat in it.

Yoshi's Island is a true 10/10 Nintendo platformer, and the one time they truly did right by Yoshi in his own games. The game is surprisingly rich in content and provides a lot of options and paths in each level, while never feeling aimless or overwhelming. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It would be the best game on SNES if:

100%ing the game wasn't made needlessly obnoxious by some bad design choices, namely having to collect everything in a level in one go, instead of only coming back for the things you missed previously, and the presence of stuff like missable red coins carried by Shy Guys that escape or one way doors and tubes that exacerbate the problem.

The extra levels weren't mostly infuriating bullshit.

The transformations weren't clunky and honestly unnecessary. It's fine when they're in self contained sub-levels when you have to fly the helicopter in the middle of a level avoiding enemies and trying to not miss collectables it's just obnoxious.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9494223
Yoshi's Island is weird because if you don't bother with the collectables you can fly through it in like 4 hours, and it's braindead easy - However, you'll also miss a lot of the best bits of design in the game.
If you DO bother with the collectables and try to 100% it, you will absolutely fucking hate Yoshi's Island by the end.

So when I play usually I just try to go for all the flowers and don't really bother with much else.

It's a great game. The fact that they just pulled that aesthetic out of the air and nailed it on the first try is remarkable to me. It also has an insanely high amount of enemies, including reintroducing Shy Guys to the Mario series which is pretty neat.

DKC and Yoshi's Island both came out relatively late in the SNES's lifespan and are both great platformers, but they're so utterly different from each other. That era was really the pinnacle of the genre for a long time.

Anyway here's a scrapped stage select that was uncovered during the gigaleak.

I mean, it did release in some form, but man, imagine how different the Sonic landscape might've been if Sonic Team had their priorities straight and swapped Sonic Adventure and NiGHTS into Dreams.
Saturn Adventure gets:
>a more focused, streamlined experience (ie. no techdemo crap like fishing)
>the swansong of the original character design aesthetic (or alternatively, the redesigns never happen because Sega wouldn't feel the need to reinvvent his image after skipping mainline 3D)
NiGHTS into Dreamcast gets:
>more exposure as a unique launch title and appropriately becomes the unofficial Dreamcast mascot
>Self content intact to extend the game's life
It's win-win.
BONUS: Sonic X-Treme potentially:
>gets further along in development due to the team not wasting weeks of work on the NiGHTS engine
>possibly far enough that Sega's PC division is interested in finishing it instead of turning it down as they did in this time-line

>>9490571

Yes.

Some GREAT fucking ST games. They are not all exclusives, but the ST versions often have their own charm:

Time Bandits https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VrvIgbsEG-A&list=PLD7CEB7FCED6C99EC&ab_channel=Chelseacf
Mudpies https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8u5uMS50qNc&ab_channel=Steve%5BAtariCrypt%5D
Sun Dog https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kg_hEY_hy9U&ab_channel=Wasabim
Major Motion https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bASGBe6jhes&ab_channel=Nival
Bratacas https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PRWzrKvqnKs&t=93s&ab_channel=W.D.Callahan
Hacker https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1SHrLhk5StY&t=379s
Hacker 2 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mOgkET76VTE&t=244s

Those are just the ones I had growing up. There are a lot more. Learn the emulator and get the roms from the pirate disks:
https://www.atarilegend.com/menusets

These are all pirate disks, you'll want to look up what's on them online, or in this site. Basically, back in the day, pirates would crack and compress games and put them into a single floppy image so people could pass around pirated games. Like, it was physical piracy. The sort of stuff you kids love to hear about. The only reason we have the ST catalog anymore is because of these pirates. Automation, Pompey Pirates, Zuul and the others. Some of these disks have viruses on them, but like... who cares? Harmless, and kinda cute!

People do still use these things for MIDI. The beat timing is PERFECT. You can't really get that perfect timing with a machine that parses time by the femtosecond. Like, a new PC just doesn't have that PERFECT beat timing, say some musicians. We could all debate this, just like we could debate vinyl versus digital, tubes versus circuits, etc.... There's a guy in LA who owns all these things and sells them for parts and replacements into the industry. I sold him pallettes of the things in the early 2000s. Shoulda charged him more.

Have fun, explore. There's a lot out there.

>>9490571
Its biggest selling point was the MIDI interface that was used in studio and hollywood productions. Had LOTS of great homebrew/shareware/independently published software packages, game experiments, and utilities. Most games were pretty close to the Amiga ports but I unfortunately have to admit a lot of big titles often ran better on the Amiga. However it was an exceptionally soulful machine and I think the much larger catalog made it work.

I don't know if anyone else will remember this, but there was a company called BRE Software that put out a periodic catalog where you could order floppy disks and they had just TONS AND TONS of random weird shit you could get, tools, programming samples, demo scene shit, ports of unix roguelikes, BBS software, etc etc. It was so great, what a wonderful wild west time in software development. Sadly the company ended up just becoming a generic Xbox/Playstation store after the 16-bit computer market died out.

>>9491037
Time Bandit is one of my all time favorite games. I love the hybrid elements of run and gun gameplay with some of the areas having different level of story/puzzle elements embedded in, mixing pure action and text adventure depending on where you go. I really feel like modern takes on these elements could do very well.

Also the GFA Basic programming language on the ST was fantastic, very powerful and expressive.

One of the most interesting things about the design of these early systems is how much of it was dictacted by the timing to drive a TV display. That's why Mister FPGA is so important as it retains this end to end system design, where the raster beam is electronically part of the system.

Now display is a few separate mostly independent systems (CPU->GPU->display) just shovel some data over.

that's because the actual onboard sound chip is kind of wimpy(they were originally going to use a custom chip for sound but didn't have time to finish it so they just used a cheap Yamaha chip that would meet the minimum needs of the computer), that's why they put the MIDI ports on in the first place, so that the end user could supply better sound themselves, that this ended up making the ST really good for sound/music production* was kind of a happy accident

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9477134
Japan has an inclination to do stories of the young because of initial post-WWII ideals. They were slower in growth and did not lend to people of that generation immediately creating new stories. It took Japan longer, like the first Godzilla struggled to get made because of anti-Japanese sentiment. It impacted them culturally and they didn't have a boom. By the time thedid rapidly expand, it was younger people making the stories, who had a different perception of WWII and Japan as a whole. since the 60's and 70's Japan has just very heavily leaned into using young people in media.

On the contrast to what the west was doing. The growth of hollywood never stopped during the war, only shifted. And the stream of stories was always on the middle aged. It wasn't till the 50's that the west also started incorporating young people into their stories.

I think FFX suffers from some slight issues, as far as intent and facts though. Auron is supposed to old at age 35 and even refers to himself as young 10 years ago, when he was 25. Yet we have a maester who has served for some 70 years. I think what happens is characters get designed and created and then put into a story and not organically written. So it's part of the overall media franchise machine.

>>9486220
Yea, very much so. In a normal play through his toolbox kit is interesting. I think Mighty Guard becomes the only really viable overdrive.

Kimahri is a litmus test for people. He can do anything except summon. On a play through he can fill any role you might want more of. FF10 is so piss ass easy I doubt anyone made him a healer. However, he is actually incredibly useful if you give him the nul-spells, especially in the parts of the game where you don't have yuna.

Putting him down Tidus's path gives another haste user and keeps his melee stats up. You can rikku him for the steal/use and still decent speed stats. Lulu's path is a unique one, as for most of the game lulu is your only nuker and you can get magic boost weapons for kimahri and he can help clean up enemies weak to that.

Wakka and Auron paths are fine, but don't offer that much, unless you just wanted to use Kimahri over those characters.

>>9488738
Late game best party = Tidus, Wakka, Rikku, with Yuna on the ready to switch for aeon to eat party wipes. You can kill everything in time before they can pwn all your aeons, just don't use their overdrive because you don't get turns afterwards. Mix, use quick hits to farm overdrives. If you are fighting Penance, you want specific armor with dmg reduction so that when you cast cheer 5x his aoe doesn't kill you in one hit. Better than break HP limit because once Rikku does trio of 9, you can use pray with anyone to heal the entire party for 9999 until the end of battle. Also you don't need high accuracy if you have high luck and celestial weapons because every hit will then crit for 99999 even through high armor like Penance and you do 1M dmg almost every turn with overdrives. Dark Sisters require different setup for optimal strat.

This is a bit misleading. The Dreamcast's real discs were a custom format with more capacity than a CD, so many (most?) games are too big to fit on a CD, and to burn them you have to use shitty scene releases that compress or remove content. You can get around this by using an ODE (optical drive emulator), but it's more expensive and complicated than just burning discs.

>The video game Duke Nukem Forever spent more than 14 years in development, from 1996 to 2011. It is a first-person shooter for Windows, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360,[1] developed by 3D Realms, Triptych Games, Gearbox Software and Piranha Games. It is the sequel to the 1996 game Duke Nukem 3D, as part of the long-running Duke Nukem video game series. Intended to be groundbreaking, it became an infamous example of vaporware due to its severely protracted development schedule; it had been in development under 3D Realms since 1996. Director George Broussard, one of the creators of the original Duke Nukem game, announced the development in 1997, and promotional information for the game was released from 1997 until its release in 2011.

>>9485398
Your post is even more misleading. Most games can be shrunk to fit on a "standard" capacity CD without removing anything but unused space. Most of what can't will fit on a larger capacity CD, which are easily obtainable by any adult with an IQ>70. There are not so shitty scene releases that compress content using more efficnet systems than the original and have negligible loss in quality. Some discs contain content that's not part of the game, not used by the game, and can be removed/moved to another disc without affecting the game in any way. In reality there are only a handfull of games where this is a real problem.
Using an ODE should be less complicated than burning discs, and not much more expensive if at all. Anyone who didn't buy GDEMUs for all their DCs when they were <$40 is a zoomer bandwagoner and thus irrelevent.

>>9484987
The Dreamcast has a lot of really solid games, but honestly the majority of them have been ported to the PC or other consoles. Unless you like shooters or fighting games, I'd recommend thinking about getting a Saturn instead. It has far more exclusives.

I had one in highschool, me and a bunch of friends all grabbed one when TRU was blowing them out for $50 on clearance. I remember playing NBA 2K1 and making a custom team filled with me and all of my friends, and we'd play games in four player mode. All of the created players based on us had all of their stats set up to maximize dunking, so we'd just do dunks after dunks on the AI teams, it was hilarious.

We'd also do shit like make custom parks for THPS2, and then bring our VMUs to school and trade parks with each other via the VMU to VMU file transfer. Shit really felt like the future back then.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Tried to convince myself that the Dreamcast was worth it.

Here's what I learned:

- GDEMU isn't worth it, most rips are ok, the only game that I played that had an issue was Bust a Move (WinCE) (can't play bgm), but it's a simple 2d game so I just emulate it instead. ask yourself, do I really need to pay +$100 usd to switch between 10 games? or just buy 10-15 cheap cds instead.
- Shenmue is worth it because it looks different than the remaster on PC, and the new redub mod was recently released. But the game has some slowdowns. Check the overclock mod if you care about more performance.
- The fan is NOISY, if you care about noise check the noctua fan mod.
- Lightgun games, if you have CRT TV go for it, LCD lightgun mods are expensive.
- Fighting games, worth playing, look and sound great, go for it unless you want to use an arcade stick.
- Resident Evil, Skies of Arcadia, Jet Set Radio, worth it.
- Soul Reaver has better models and effects that the PC version, worth it.
- Tony Hawk 2 runs at 30fps. Xbox has better textures and it's a different game (2X), better version, but dreamcast has the "proper classic" version.
- Rayman 2 worth it because it's closer to the "classic" version.
- The 480p picture quality makes this console a MUST. It's amazing to play 90s games in this resolution.
- DCHDMI isn't worth it. I got a $25 usd VGA box from AliExpress that also outputs HDMI and the picture quality is amazing, I have an OLED B7 that actually does a great job upscaling the 480p output.
- The controller is a hit and miss, the camera control in Soul Reaver with the D-pad is just horrendous with that layout.

So: small library, but amazing picture quality, and iconic games, IMO expensive mods like DCHDMI and GDEMU are a waste of money, check the library, you will have a great time with this console, but probably just with a dozen of games lol, currently playing Skies of Arcadia and Soul Reaver.

>>9497880
As time goes on, the manufacture and design improves in cost, efficiency, and sometimes quality. Since taking a lot of controllers and consoles apart for cleaning through the years, I can observe the changes. Dualshock controllers have a lot of revisions even within each model. Here you can see the black Dualshock 2 has a more complicated PCB with the plastic holster for the board with only one motor with the larger imbalanced weights, while the other uses a set of smaller weights on the other directly clipped by the shell. The other translucent controllers are newer, featuring contract pads not on the silicone/rubber membranes. You can best see clearly through the yellow one the weights on those versions are 4 left to 1 right of the same size.

So I've been trying to understand, how exactly is Mega Drive viewed in Japan? Anyone who can contribute on this topic?
I've been looking at the game sales to get a general idea. There doesn't seem to be much data on game sales available, but the 2 lists Ive found paint a pretty similar picture—and it's pretty interesting.
Ironically, the #1 game on MD supposedly was Puyo Puyo. And looks like Sonic was quite popular on it, ending the meme that "no one knows Sonic in Japan"—MD simply sold like shit, and Sonic with it.
That said, the top was clearly dominated by RPGs, with Shining and Phantasy Star, and even games like Langrisser 2. No wonder Sega later wanted to have more RPGs on the platform.
Mega CD sold relatively well in Japan, so a few games for it made it to the top, like, interestingly, Silpheed, an even a fucking Night Trap.
Anyway, it's pretty surprising to see a list like this. Then again, it's clear that action games were far more popular in the West than in Japan, and it clearly had more appeal there with stuff like Streets of Rage, Golden Axe, Comix Zone, all the platformers, Mortal Kombat, sports games, and so on.

A chart comparing the console sales also sheds some light on the subject. Basically, MD was more or less doing ok, competing with PCE until around 1991-92. But then, SFC released and quickly overtook both of them. Sega CD helped slightly, but then again, PCE also had the CD add-on and Turbo Duo, which did better.
All in all, I guess Sega's arcade titles didn't really mean that much in Japan. What people wanted was Dragon Quest and Final Fantasy, and they continued buying the console that gave it to them until mid 2000s. Also, Nintendo was still strong after the success of the Famicom, and basically the competition had no chance going toe to toe with them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9496158
Japan cared more about Square / Enix, and way less so about arcade action, so SFC dominated there. But in the West, they cared way more about action, sports and mascot platformers, so one of Nintendo's biggest advantages meant very little there.
Also note that almost all of the best-selling SFC games in Japan were exclusives (save for a few like Street Fighter 2 or Puyo Puyo). But in the West, again due to popularity of the sports and cartoon games, a lot of the biggest sellers were multiplats. Mortal Kombat, NFL / NBA Jam, Aladdin, Lion King etc. came out on both platforms. So again, the gap narrowed hard. Genesis getting a lot of Western developer titles also didn't help.
And yes, Sega's marketing and Ninty's kiddy image in the West could've hurt too, but it's hard to say how much.
Regardless, data may vary, but according to NPD, Genesis was often beating SNES (albeit not by much) until late '94. It took DKC for Nintendo to truly give an answer to Sega. (see https://www.sega-16.com/forum/showthread.php?26110-January-December-1994-NPD-sales-data! ).

>>9498526
Simply put, it's a more complex game. You forget that your average normie wouldn't even understand rotating camera / the whole Mario moveset / complicated puzzles / etc. Have you seen women play video games? They often can't even figure out basic stuff like holding B to run.
Every lost dummy like that is a lost sale on the market. That's the big reason a lot of the modern games have been dumbed down so much, with hour long tutorials like "press up to go forward".
Whole genres have seen this fate, like e.g. death of RTS and switch to MOBA. Because of increased budgets, you need to sell at least a million or more units just to break even. You have to target more people, and reach out to non-gamers. Appealing to a bunch of hardcore nerds isn't feasible in these conditions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9496891
Joust 2, obscure by the virtue that most people don't know there even was a sequel. It didn't do as well as the original, since it came out with graphics and sound on par with the original years later. Which is a shame, since the game can be considered an expert level challenge for pros of the first game. Similar concept and gameplay except now you can change between your fast flying ostrich and a slow but good in combat lion or dragon or something. Switching between the two effectively is the key to success, but very difficult to learn.

I just think guest cap should increase proportionate to a ride's length up to like 300 meters. A 300+ length ride gets its full guest draw, an amount shorter gets a proportionally reduced amount of guests to the park as a mini-ride merits. It's the guest cap increase that really breaks microcoasters; as simple moneymakers they're not as massively superior to a coaster with good throughput.

But any sweeping balance changes like this would need to be an optional checkbox for me to be okay with modifying the game so heavily.

>>9481894
Yeah, that's a bald-headed lie. I did the math for shits and giggles. Built a helix stack with a station at top and bottom, took ride length for that segment over number of turns to get circumference and hence radius of curvature: 11.8m. Convert 130kph to m/s and a = v^2/r = 11.2g.

Taking a two-unit (3m) high volume of space to be a cube, a medium turn spans, square-center to square-center, 5 squares for a 15m diameter and 17.7g.

the magnitude of the G force would be that number. The component forces (lateral and positive) would be separate components of each

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The circular force would be split via bank between lateral and vertical as sides of a triangle - meaning the values obey the pythagorean theorem (a^2+b^2=c^2). So the more conservative/accurate figure of 11g could be softened to something like 7.5g and 8g. Still no bueno.

I kinda agree. I beat GTA III twice this week, and I think that its strength is that it realizes it's mostly a driving game with car theft and light combat being a little deviation to spice up the gameplay. When you approach the game primarily as a driving game, you're going to get better mission design, because it focuses on what the game does well: the driving. When you start to put more of a focus on combat without the combat mechanics getting exponentially better, you've made more focus on the janky aspects of the game.

Still love VC and SA. Love them for what they are, but I also feel that III set out to do what it intended better than those two games did.

>>9496679
Okay so the way the powerups work is that each colour is a different type of attack. To upgrade them you need to collect the same colour repeatedly without collecting the other colours, otherwise you go back to the lv1 version of the collected weapon. Try it, it will make a huge difference. Melee enemies that get close because itll either oneshot them or knock them back giving you room for a charge shot. They have very basic patterns to play around once you know how they work. Boss of stage 1 is a bit of a pain if you dont know the patterns and some require you get into position before the attack comes out. If the turret is spinning one way try to be one the end of that rotation so you have enough time to read the pattern before youre expected to dodge. Shifting levels and ducking is effective. You can do it!
